author: SantiaguitoLoquito
body: Ha, I looked up what TXN was and was delighted to learn that it was TI.  I actually worked as a temp in their consumer products division warehouse for six months in the late 80s after I graduated from college and was trying to find a "real" job.  My job was to sort all the returned and defective products and put them into bins, then take them over to the repair people who refurbished them.  I have fond memories of that place.

author: shinystacks
body:
From my portfolio, in order of highest div yield to lowest: AVGO (2.89%), JPM, BX, DAC, TXN, CG, HD, TROW, ALLY, QCOM, NEE, TGT, UNH, TSM, ACN, CARR, MSFT, COST, EL (.62%).

I chose these positions as I felt they had a good blend of company growth, dividend growth, and current yield.

author: Draiko
body:
Oh for fuck's sake... [the Lehi fab was equipped for 3D Xpoint, not DDR production.](https://www.anandtech.com/show/16800/micron-sells-lehi-3d-xpoint-fab-to-texas-instruments-for-900m)

Computer demand is skyrocketing, fool. It's going to continue to grow for the next 5+ years too. Computers need RAM and, I'll say this again, all of the chipsets launching at the end of 2021 and beyond are all going ***DDR5-only.***

Dude, you need to do some damned research.

author: aurora4000
body:
Semiconductors are diverse, and are in cars, phones, appliances, laptops, gaming systems, cameras, etc. Each semi category is quite different and needs to be analyzed by someone who understand that category, industry and chipmaker. 

Chipmakers include: AAPL, GOOG, MRVL, MU, AMD, NVDA, INTC, TXN, LRCX. 

Good analysts include Bofa Securities - they published an amazing piece on NVDA last month. I'd link to it except that the mods might smite my post.

author: Celetus
body:
TXN might merit some interest as well for sure. Yes they have higher margins, but their level of growth and their valuation does not really merit a place in my semiconductor portfolio. Frankly, there are so many good companies in this industry that it is incredibly hard to limit yourself to a handful.

In regards to the fund, Intel is also making a play for it (see link). I think come within 10 years there is a real chance that Intel might become a real contender again as they seek to take on AMD, NVDA and TSM at the same time.

https://www.nasdaq.com/articles/intel-is-positioning-itself-to-make-the-comeback-of-the-century-2021-08-25

author: samuelj264
body:
Depends on the type of account for 1. If its a qualified account (401k, IRA, Roth IRA) that is non-taxable so you dont have to worry about capital gains.

If its an Individual, Joint, Trust, etc. that means its taxable. Any sales you make you'll have to pay taxes on.

My personal advice is to leave it in $VTI and dont look at it for 5/10 years. If you want to play around and trade some money. See how much in taxes it would cost to sell $10k and then use that 10k as "fun money" you have to be prepared to loose all of it. At your age let the VTI stay invested and get compounded returns. If you want to learn about trading and investments, read some more here, watch educational videos about economics, trading, and long term investing. Start small with Blue Chip names (AAPL, CAT, TXN, MSFT, HD, JPM, etc.) then build your way up to more risky names as you become more comfortable.

If spx for borrowing, max loss is established at start of trade and is the difference between the executed price and the width of the strikes. 4500-4000 strikes width is 500. Mid of say 495 means max loss is 5. $100 a point for spx. Interest cost of your loan is $500.

Box spread to make profit? Don't bother. Early assignment and txn costs not worth. 1ronyman etc etc

author: tloffman
body:
You are fooling yourself. I have been trading for 40 years and have lived through many huge drops. If you want to sell puts, fine, but sell a vertical spread. Your "it won't happen to me" arrogance will lead to your eventual financial demise in the market. It's just a matter of time. 

I will give you an example of an actual trade that I am in now. A couple of weeks ago TXN had a 5% drop after earnings were released. It settled near 185, and had been at that level previously and recovered. So, I sold the Aug 20 182.5 put, and bought the 180 put. I took in .87 premium, or $87 per spread, minus commissions. TXN has since recovered and is now near 192-3, and the spread is at .12. If TXN stays about 182.5 on 8/20 the puts will expire worthless. If the market tanks my risk is limited to $163 per spread. If I were only short the 182.5 put my risk would be unlimited. Many hedge funds have been wiped out selling naked puts, so don't kid yourself into thinking it won't happen to you. Risk management is the key to surviving stock market trading.

author: tloffman
body:
I am telling you about the dangers because I have "been there, done that". I have wiped out a million dollars a couple of times. 

I can tell from your comments that you are new to trading. When you sell a naked put, how many do you sell? Can you define your risk?

Here's how I decide how many put spreads to sell. Let's say my account size is 10k. I want to risk no more than 2% in a worse case scenario. So, the spread (in my case TXN) is to sell the 182.5 put and buy the 180 put. The spread is 2.5 pts or $250. I take (did take in) .87, or $87 per spread. My risk is $250-87, or $163. For 10k risking 2% that's $200 of risk, so I can sell 1 TXN spread. I have taken in $87, and set aside $200 for the trade - that's 43.5% for a 4 week holding period. Not a bad gain. 

The problem with naked put selling is you don't know your max potential risk, so you don't know how many to sell. With a vertical put spread you do know you max potential loss so you can easily calculate exactly how many spreads to sell. 

For full disclosure I am short 23 of the TXN spreads.

author: MonoDun
body: Peaks are the most dangerous positions to be at.....and we are at the Mother. Of. All. Peaks. ^tm or M.O.A.P.S in **everything.** The sentiment called greed can trigger a engineered crash where the whales can crash it, make money on the way up/down. Apple will turn into something like Ford, Intel, Texas Instruments, Coca Cola with a few ER misses, it's a generational guarantee, my best guess is in about two years. Why ? its called 'Brand Fatigue'.
